title: 105_s1224
content: The Act titled "Federal Facility Superfund Compliance Act of 1997" amends Section 120 of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 to address federal entities and facilities. The Act "Federal Facility Superfund Compliance Act of 1997" amends Section 120 of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 to define service charges related to permits, reviews, inspections, and other assessments. Each department, agency, and instrumentality of the executive, legislative, or judicial branch of the United States must comply with the Act and all federal, state, interstate, and local laws related to response actions, hazardous waste management, and pollutants. The Act requires all government entities to comply with environmental laws, including permit and reporting requirements, injunctive relief, and cleanup liability provisions. The United States waives immunity for compliance with environmental laws, including cleanup liability, reimbursement of costs, contribution, payment of damages, service charges, administrative orders, and penalties. The United States waives immunity for compliance with environmental laws, including cleanup liability, reimbursement of costs, contribution, payment of damages, service charges, administrative orders, and penalties. The waiver of sovereign immunity does not apply if a State law imposes more stringent standards on Federal entities than on other persons. Civil and criminal liability apply to the United States and its agents, employees, and officers. No personal liability for civil penalties for agents, employees, or officers of the United States in relation to response actions or management of hazardous substances within official duties. An agent, employee, or officer of the United States is not personally liable for criminal sanctions related to response actions or management of hazardous substances. The Administrator may issue orders for abatement actions under section 106. The Administrator can issue an order under section 106 to any department, agency, or instrumentality of the United States, initiating an administrative enforcement action in the same manner as against any other person. No order to a US department shall become final until it has had the opportunity to consult. The Administrator can issue orders to US departments, agencies, or instrumentalities for enforcement actions. Funds collected as penalties must be used for environmental projects or enforcement costs. The text chunk discusses the right to contribution under section 113 for US departments, agencies, or instrumentalities resolving liability under the Act. It also mentions the exclusion of indemnification requirements in certain cases and the preservation of State authority in interagency agreements. The curr_chunk discusses the jurisdiction of courts to enforce compliance with State or Federal law, unless specifically addressed in agreements or waived without objection.
